text: hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Indian
album from all purity Annie what's going
on with your tip over there here it's
not a big deal it's just hair well it's
on your head too
we're we're we're Indian is a metal
outfit from Chicago this is their fifth
full-length LP their second for relapse
records I first heard of these guys back
in 2011 through their previous
full-length LP guiltless and album that
showed a huge jump in recording quality
from Indians old stuff and their newer
stuff the band took their already
booming and abrasive sound and made it
heavier and more hard-hitting and this
larger grander scope in fidelity also
allowed them to experiment more with
melody and noise too now anything in
Indian songs that might be the least bit
catchy or accessible is only ever a side
dish too brittle harsh guitar distortion
that's melted in with the bass guitar
which is incredibly heavy and these two
instruments are fused together to the
point where the guitars just create this
pummeling white noise wall of sound a
lot of Indians tracks have some really
primal drums wretched black metal
influenced vocals that are very throaty
and disgusting yeah and all of these
things are played at a tick or two
slower than they were on Indians
previous LPS the band really sought out
to create this harsh overbearing
atmosphere that slowly scratches away at
what little hope you have left for the
world and it works the most notable
change in pace on this record in terms
of Indians sound is their use of noise a
lot of tracks here make use of
additional effects and just ear piercing
sounds making the six tracks here
incredibly unpleasant to listen to and I
definitely would not call Indians
previous records easy-listening and they
are one of those bands that slowly fine
Tunes their
own record to record but if there is any
one element that you can pull out of
this album and say whoa this is where
they're headed it is with just a noise
torch held high even the track clarify
on this record is this four minute and
30 second noise interlude with all of
these harsh tones and pieces of
distortion and just dissonance creating
this putrid landscape while vocals are
thrown on top it's very hellish and as
vile
and as disgusting and as unsettling as
some of the tracks are on here they
reach this level of nastiness that is
kind of inspiring like on the track
directional which behind the very huge
monolithic riffs that play in the
foreground there are walls of distortion
and feedback screaming away in the
background and as the track progresses
some of this noise hanging back there
gets kind of glitchy and keep in mind
the riff that is playing in the
foreground it does not change up in a
significant way as the track progresses
this is a very mind-numbing
soul-crushing song there are slight
changes of pace from track to track like
on the song the impetus bleeds which is
easily the most melodic song in this
entire LP a bit of doom metal with some
very sad mournful guitar leads it
reminds me a little bit of that
pallbearer album that dropped a few
years back and even though the song is
incredibly harsh I do think the very sad
sad guitar playing and chord
progressions on this track do make it a
little more digestible and then there's
the track rhetoric of no which is easily
the most visceral exciting hard-hitting
song in this entire LP you really picks
up the pace in the tempo a little bit
and deliver some riffs that really you
can Bob your head to but with how
aggressively this song starts it should
be no surprise that the ending of this
song is one of the most ear-splitting
moments on this entire album and then
there's the finale on here
disambiguation a track that I wish
lasted a little bit longer
I wish didn't cut off so abruptly the
album overall is 40 minutes long and
with something that really kind of tries
to draw your lifeforce away from you
very slowly I do wish it was [ __ ] but
she added
ten minutes of soul-sucking misery
either way this is one of the most
extreme tracks on this entire LP with
the song the riffs the noise getting
louder and harsher and just ooh just
every bar that passes by the song just
incrementally gets more and more and
more the riffs just get heavier and
heavier there's some black metal style
melodies that sort of introduced
themselves in the second half of this
song - I like that on this song and some
others here too like the opener as well
Indian does manage to take some of these
very very harsh songs and just raise the
heat on them so slowly that you don't
even realize it's happening unless you
compare the end of one song to the
beginning of one song and while that
doesn't sound all that pleasurable in
theory and I'm not promising that
everybody is going to like what Indian
has to offer on this record it does
create a certain emotional or auditory
sensation that I find to be very
powerful very disturbing in a way
overall what Indian does on this record
is take doom metal fuse it with Noise
music for an incredibly hideous set of
songs what I'm hearing on this record
really reminds me of the music of bands
like I hate God but push to a more
dismal and grating extreme and while a
lot of the sounds on this record do make
me wince I simultaneously have a bit of
a morbid infatuation with what goes on
with this record as well I do think some
people will have issues with this record
seeing it as being redundant or kind of
OneNote and that's fine there are no
rays of sunshine that peaked through the
clouds but personally I wish there was a
bit more diversity on this thing a bit
more experimentation maybe Indian could
let go of some of their metal roots and
sort of dive more wholeheartedly into
Noise music or see what space could
actually do you know sort of leaving
moments of quiet in the midst of their
very hard-hitting songs and see what
that does for making for a very jarring
auditory experience because they were
seeking to do anything it was that
something jarring I am feeling a light
to decent 8 on this thing transition if
you've given this record to listen what
did you think of it did you love it hate
it why what do you think I should review
next and that's it
Anthony Fantana Indian forever
